ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
HANDPHONE USERS
(Time-based charging)


    1. Mr Choo Wee Khiang asked the Minister for Communications whether he will consider applying the principle of time-based charging to handphone users.

     The Minister for Communications (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, handphone users today are already paying according to usage. Apart from the subscription of $50 per month, they pay a traffic charge of 20 cents per minute for both incoming as well as outgoing calls.

     Mr Choo Wee Khiang (Jalan Besar GRC): Sir, I must declare that I am a handphone user. I pay the bills every month and I know there is a flat rate charge. But what I want the Minister --

Column: 738



     Mr Speaker: Mr Choo, could you ask your question?

     Mr Choo Wee Khiang: Yes. Could the Ministry consider, instead of charging a flat rate of 20 cents per minute, a two-tier charging system, like in the case of residential telephones, ie, to differentiate between off-peak and peak periods?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the residential telephone subscribers enjoy a peak and off-peak tariff structure mainly because there is a very distinct peak and off-peak usage pattern. When Telecom charges the off-peak rate, which is half the peak period rate, there is sufficient capacity during the off-peak period for such off-peak traffic to be handled. However, I do not think there is such a distinct peak/off-peak usage pattern for handphone users. Nevertheless, I will ask Telecom to look into this matter and see whether it is feasible to implement an off-peak rate.

    Head V --

     Mr Davinder Singh (Toa Payoh GRC): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head V of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, in 1990, I had in this House suggested developing a system of accountability to give the man-in-the-street some assurance that he has been fairly treated by Government departments. I have suggested the appointment of an ombudsman and a change in the present system which does not require reasons to be given when decisions are handed down by Government

Column: 743

bodies. I made those suggestions for a number of reasons.

    It was my feeling then that there was a growing demand for more accountability on the part of the Government and that this demand ought to be accommodated. It was also my view that it was important for Singaporeans to believe that their applications have been fairly considered. These reasons continue to remain valid today. This Government has always looked for ways to meet the aspirations of a sophisticated population. The Feedback Unit is one way. The Service Improvement Unit is another. The question is whether these steps are sufficient and, if not, what other measures ought to be put in place for this purpose.

    What we should ultimately seek to achieve is a situation where people's grievances can be expressed outside the ballot box and this will reduce the prospect of an unhappy result at an election if there are more avenues available for the people to do this.

    Our system of public administration is vast and complex. Government departments and statutory bodies have numerous functions and with them extensive powers. Whenever these powers are exercised, someone is affected either marginally or substantially and, in some cases, a person's livelihood is dependent or affected by Government decisions.

    Sir, as MPs, we are continually making appeals on behalf of our constituents. In a normal case, what happens is that a constituent writes in, in the first instance, to the Ministry or department in question. And if he is unsuccessful, he receives a standard form rejection notice. Very rarely does he get reasons for the rejection. And then he comes to his MP who in effect basically resubmits the application but with this difference. He writes an explanation of the merits of the case. But really when MPs do this, they are groping in the dark because they do not really know the basis of the decisions. They do not know if the guidelines have been properly applied. So the MP's task in this respect is not assisted to a large extent.

Column: 744


12.45 pm

    The difficulty, we are told, is that there are a whole host of guidelines and criteria which are sensitive, and that it is not in the public interest to reveal them to the constituents. I accept that in some cases. But while I may accept that, there is this difficulty that the man who has had his application turned down will not be happy with the fact that he cannot know the reasons or he cannot know what criteria he has to meet in order to successfully apply.

    Therefore, what we want to achieve is a compromise between not divulging sensitive matters and, at the same time, assuring the public that the merits of their respective cases have been fairly considered. The way to do this, as I said in the past and I repeat now, is to create an office of an Ombudsman or a Parliamentary Commissioner, as some countries call it. This office will enable members of the public to air their grievances and to be given the opportunity to have these grievances investigated into, to ascertain that Government departments or statutory bodies have actually applied correct principles, have not acted arbitrarily or have not overlooked any relevant criteria.

    It is in effect another check and balance that I am suggesting. And as all checks and balances, we have to be careful in crafting the powers of this office or its functions. We do not want a situation where the Ombudsman usurps Government functions. He should not be allowed to question legislation or policy or guidelines, but he should have powers to look into files as and when matters are brought to his attention and in his discretion. Having powers to look into files does not mean having the power or the right to disclose details of these files to anybody else.

    Secondly, he should be given the opportunity to meet with the decision makers after such investigations to persuade them to review or change the decisions. It does not have to go public. If we want to start, we can keep it within a narrow framework and make it a very private affair. But as long as the public feels that there is an

Column: 745

independent and impartial person looking at it, I think there is greater confidence in the way the system operates.

    Sir, the last time I made this suggestion, it was not implemented and I would not be surprised again if this suggestion is not accepted. I understand the reason is that we have a very clean, honest and efficient civil service. That everyone accepts. But it is a suggestion that I make not only for the present but also for the future. Whatever the virtues of our civil service, an additional check and balance will, in my view, ensure that the present excellent track record will continue.

     The Minister for Law (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Prime Minister has asked me to answer this question.

    Sir, it cannot be denied that the idea behind the office of the Ombudsman is in principle a good one, that is, there should be a check against maladministration and that citizens who feel that they have suffered an injustice or have any other grievance as a result of decisions of civil servants or Government bodies, have a channel to make their complaints and to obtain redress. Whether we should have the office of the Ombudsman in Singapore, the question really is whether there is a real and pressing need now for such an institution in Singapore. Or to put it in the way Mr Davinder Singh has put it, are the avenues and mechanisms available adequate or not adequate for those who have grievances on a Government decision and who want it to be looked into?

    If we quickly look at the available avenues, first of all, within Parliament, we have Question Time which MPs can use. And if it is used effectively, it can be quite a useful vehicle for taking on the Ministers and Ministries on specific decisions and policies, and MPs have done this. And MPs have meet-the-people sessions. Every Government department receives many letters and representations from MPs which are looked into and answers given. MPs also write to Ministers and I speak for the Frontbench when I say that when the Minister receives a letter from an MP, he

Column: 746

looks into it personally, and it is not just handled by the civil servants.

    Then there is the Feedback Unit and the Service Improvement Unit (SIU) mentioned by Mr Davinder Singh. The Feedback Unit, established by Government, submits feedback to Government departments and they have to give replies. Similarly with the SIU, when complaints are addressed to SIU, these are investigated and replies given. Citizens write to the press, replies are given by Government departments. TV has Feedback, Points of View and other programmes.

    Then we have the CPIB. Of course, the CPIB really investigates the more serious complaints of corruption. But even when CPIB concludes that there is no offence of corruption but the facts disclose some wrongdoing which may warrant disciplinary action, the CPIB does refer the matter to the relevant department or Ministry and disciplinary actions are instituted.

    For these reasons, therefore, while the thinking behind the office of the Ombudsman is laudable, I do not see any pressing need at the moment for introduction of the office, because there are these other avenues. If I may add, Sir, we can devise, of course, as many new procedures, institutions and mechanisms that we can think of. But what counts in the ultimate analysis really is whether we have an honest government that does not cover up and does not condone abuse of power, wrongdoing, malpractices and corruption. Equally important is whether we have a civil service whose competence and integrity is beyond doubt. If we do not have these elements and this commitment and attitude of the Government, then no amount of Ombudsman can really prevent maladministration, because they themselves will be absorbed into this corrupt and incompetent administration.

    We have operated our system of government successfully without an Ombudsman for some 32 years. Mr Davinder Singh himself says we have an excellent record. There has been no major complaint of maladministration. And if there were complaints against the civil service, MPs

Column: 747

have not failed to bring them up in Parliament or with Ministers or the Prime Minister, and these have been resolved. Since our present system has worked and we have people of integrity and competence, both in Government and the civil service, if we continue this, then the system will continue to work.

    Head W --

     The Chairman: Head W - Ministry of Trade and Industry. Amendment No. (1), we have 80 minutes, Dr Ow.

     Dr Ow Chin Hock (Leng Kee)( In Mandarin): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head W of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, two days ago, I mentioned that productivity and the quality of the local workforce are very important factors affecting the future growth of our economy. However, some people believe that our average productivity growth of 3.8% for the last five years is very close to our long-term target growth of 3% to 4%. There is no need for us to play this game of numbers. If you take a 5-year average, you can also take a 10-year average. If we take a 10-year period, the average productivity growth rate is 4.2%, which is even higher. What is apparent to us is that our productivity growth rate has been dropping successively from 6.3% in 1986 to 1.5% last year. This may reflect our shortage of labour and, perhaps, the labour stockpiling practices by some employers or due to some other factors I mentioned two days ago.

Column: 748



    Over the past three years, the growth in productivity was lower than the real increase in wages, resulting in an increase in unit labour cost. However, I do not agree that we should use this as an excuse to curb increase in wages. Because in a tight labour market, wage increase is inevitable and it is the result of free market operation. So if we intentionally press down the wages, it will result in a misallocation of resources. It would also result in a vicious cycle of "low wages, lower productivity and lower wages".

    Therefore, what we must do is to increase productivity. Although there is an increase in wages, if productivity can be increased correspondingly, then this will buffer the pressure exerted by the increase in unit labour cost. In order to increase productivity, the best way, of course, is to concentrate on education and training of the workers. The National Productivity Board (NPB) has announced that in the next three years, expenditure on training of workers will be increased from the present 2.3% of the payroll to 4% of the payroll. This is a very good strategy. Because in our workforce, 19.4% of our workers have no formal education and another 29.3% of our workers have only primary or post primary education. In order to enhance our competitiveness internationally, we have to try our best to improve the quality of our workforce and this is the imminent task in our next lap of economic development.

    On this issue, I have two suggestions. First, we must have more traduing courses in the mother tongue. In the past, technical training courses were mainly or completely conducted in English, resulting in many workers who do not speak or understand English hesitating in coming forward to attend these training courses. In Town Councils, factories and workshops, I often hear Chinese contractors, electricians, technicians and maintenance workers conversing with one another in Chinese, mixed with a smattering of technical terms and names of spare parts in English. So I feel that if the NPB and the NTUC can conduct more courses in non-English, e.g. Chinese, it will be more effective in the

Column: 749

introduction of new technology to these non-English speaking workers, in order to upgrade their skills. We have to be down-to-earth. We must use a practical method to help these non-speaking English workers in order that more of them may be upgraded to the rank of skilled workers. This will be good not only for the nation, but also to the workers as well. I would like to ask the Minister how many of these non-English training courses have been conducted by NPB and what is the response to these courses? What measures has the relevant authority taken to encourage more workers to participate in such courses?

    My second suggestion concerns on-the-job training. I have just mentioned that about 49% of our workers have no formal education. Formal education is the basis for good learning. However, formal education alone is not enough. According to the authors and editors of the book published by MIT entitled Make in America, on-the-job training is more effective in increasing productivity than formal education. In the book, two models were described. The first model is called Model A where emphasis is on school education and workers were cultivated to be specialised in one skill. The second model is Model B which takes after the Japanese and the German models, and it emphasizes on-the-job training where workers are cultivated to obtain diversified skills, and they will be more quality conscious and readily adaptable to changes. If we compare the models, the advantages and disadvantages become apparent. We should follow Model B which takes after the Japanese and German models, and encourage and assist the enterprises to provide more on-the-job training to our workers.

    I would like to know whether the relevant authority has a comprehensive plan to assist the various enterprises in implementing on-the-job training for their workers. The Japanese believe that the development of talents is a way to increase the assets of the enterprises. Apart from striving for technological breakthroughs, the Japanese also go for loyalty and job excellence in order to further improve productivity. The

Column: 750

Chinese have a very good tradition of respecting and loving the work that they are doing. If our workers can maintain this spirit, together with more technical training, and the willingness to pursue life-long learning for better skill, then we will have strong competitiveness. Even in the face of intense competition from the various countries and territories for international market shares, we can still prosper amidst all the changes.

     Mr Chew Heng Ching (Eunos GRC): Sir, I have three amendments under this subhead. Can I take them together?

     The Chairman: I would prefer that you follow the order shown in the Order Paper Supplement as there are quite a number of Members who would like to speak.

     Mr Chew Heng Ching: Yes. Sir, I think much has been said about the widening gap between wages and productivity growth in the last two days' debate. This widening gap is certainly a cause for concern, as expressed by many fellow Members here. There could be various reasons. Many have interpreted that they were due to employers trying to hoard workers, paying them more in the present tight labour market situation with the hope that when the economy recovers, they have the manpower resources to meet their economic needs. Others attribute the trend to declining productivity gain due to the poor attitude of some of our workers.

    Sir, I would like an official explanation from the Ministry of Trade and Industry, on what causes this widening gap between wages and productivity growth? What are the implications, and whether the Ministry is taking corrective actions to reverse this trend?

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon (Yuhua): Sir, the announcement by the Finance Minister that productivity growth for 1991 has decreased from 3.5% to 1.5% is quite alarming. I understand that this substantial drop in productivity is very much due to the economic slowdown without a reduction of the workforce. This is particularly so in the financial, retail and manufacturing sectors. It is important for us to find out

Column: 751

how much of the decline in productivity growth is due to the economic slowdown and how much is due to the relatively low education and skill levels of our workforce.

    For nine years, Singapore has been ranked 14th by BERI in terms of the skills level of our workers. With the exception of Taiwan, the countries ranked above us are all highly industrialised countries. These countries, such as Japan and Germany, have a long history and emphasis on workers' training and re-training.

    Over the last few years, the Ministry of Trade and Industry and the National Productivity Board have come out with various training schemes and financial incentives to encourage skills training.
